Friends so far 2012 has given the group many Italian films to watch. :)  Thursday and Friday movies start at 7PM. Saturday & Sunday movies start at 2pm. 

April 12, 2012 Italian Film Weekend Opening Night: The Man Who Will Come

The Man Who Will Come (L’uomo che Verra): Set in 1943 in a rural area of Italy, the film tells the story of a family struggling to survive as Nazi troops move into Italy. Winner of 13 Awards.  2009. 115 min. Not Rated. Directed by Giorgio Diritti.

Tonight’s screening includes complimentary Prosecco and Italian desserts! This film is being screened as part of our Italian Film Weekend, showcasing dominant themes explored by Italian filmmakers. These themes include family ties, religion, and poverty. Join us for a weekend of screenings and discussions celebrating recent Italian cinema and the depiction of the Italian “famiglia.” All films have subtitles. The Italian Film Weekend is supported by Camille and Gregory Servodidio.

General Admission: $9, Seniors and Students w/i.d.: $8, Members: $7, Film Buff: $3.50, Film Stars: Free, Senior 62+.

April 13, 2012 Italian Film Weekend: The First Beautiful Thing

 The First Beautiful Thing (La Prima Cosabella): This comedic drama depicts a misanthropic professor who struggles to come to terms with his childhood when he is summoned to his hometown to visit his dying mother. Italy’s Best Foreign Language Film Submission for 2010. 2010. 122 min. Not Rated. Directed by Paolo Virzì.

April 14, 2012 Italian Film Weekend: The Best of Youth

Don’t miss The Best of Youth (La Meglio Gioventu) during our Italian Film Weekend!This beautiful family saga follows the loves and lives of two brothers over four decades. Winner of 23 Awards. 2003. 366 min. Rated R. Directed by Marco Tullio Giordana.

April 15, 2012 Italian Film Weekend: Bread & Tulips

Don’t miss Bread & Tulips (Pane y Tulipani) during our Italian Film Weekend! In this charming comedy, a housewife decides to start a new life in Venice after accidentally being left behind by her family at a highway café. Winner of 24 Awards. 2003. 114 min. Rated PG13. Directed by Silvio Soldini.
